link_data_node.linkDataPagetext: The "Link Data" function shows associations between environmental health data at the neighborhood level using <a href="http://a816-dohbesp.nyc.gov/IndicatorPublic/Glossary.aspx?#Scatterplot" target="_blank">scatterplots.</a> The points represent x and y values for each NYC neighborhood. The pairs of indicators available for scatterplots were chosen because previous research suggests that one may either directly or indirectly cause or contribute to the other. Because the data being charted are <a href="http://a816-dohbesp.nyc.gov/IndicatorPublic/Glossary.aspx?#Ecological_Study" target="_blank">ecological</a> and not individual level, and because many factors contribute to the health of a population or environment, the patterns seen in these charts do not necessarily represent the underlying causal relationship.

Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood Asthma Hospitalizations - Children ages 5 to 14 by Sulfur Dioxide (SO2)
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 14 Yrs Old) - Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2016

info.info_how_calculated: Data collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specified time period. The results were then smoothed using GIS, assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood, and averaged. The gaseous pollutants in NYC are measured in units of parts per billion.
info.info_source: New York City Community Air Survey

info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood Asthma Hospitalizations - Children ages 5 to 14 by Ozone (O3)
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 14 Yrs Old) - Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2016

info.info_how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specified time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and averaged. In NYC, ozone is measured in units of parts per billion (ppb).
info.info_source: New York City Community Air Survey

info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood Asthma Hospitalizations - Children ages 5 to 14 by Black Carbon
Compare.y_axis_title: Black Carbon - Mean (absorbance units) Annual Average 2016
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 14 Yrs Old) - Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2016

info.info_how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specified time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and averaged. Black carbon levels are estimated using a method that measures absorbance.
info.info_source: New York City Community Air Survey

info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Compare.y_axis_title: Fine Particulate Matter (PM2.5) - Mean (mcg per cubic meter) Annual Average 2016
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 14 Yrs Old) - Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2016

info.info_how_calculated: Air samples collected at specific NYCCAS monitoring sites along with information about emissions sources were incorporated into a statistical model that predicted pollutant concentrations at all locations in NYC for the specified time period. The results were then assigned to the appropriate NYC neighborhood and averaged. In NYC, fine particulate matter is measured in units of micrograms per cubic meter of air.
info.info_source: New York City Community Air Survey

info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Compare.compare_type: Renter-Occupied Homes with No Maintenance Deficiencies (Percent)
Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood Asthma Hospitalizations - Children ages 5 to 14 by Renter-Occupied Homes with No Maintenance Deficiencies
Compare.y_axis_title: Renter-Occupied Homes with No Maintenance Deficiencies - Percent 2014
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 14 Yrs Old) - Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2014

info.y_axis_title_reg: Renter-Occupied Homes with No Maintenance Deficiencies
info.info_name: Renter-Occupied Homes with No Maintenance Deficiencies
info.info_how_calculated: Estimated number of renter-occupied households in an area reporting no maintenance deficiencies (heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, rodent infestation, cracks/holes in the walls, ceilings or floors, broken plaster/peeling paint larger than 8 x 11 inches, toilet breakdowns, or water leaks from outside the unit), divided by the number of renter-occupied households in the area; expressed as percent..
info.info_source: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

info.y_axis_title_reg: Renter-Occupied Homes with No Maintenance Deficiencies
info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Compare.compare_type: Homes with Cracks or Holes (Percent of Households)
Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood Asthma Hospitalizations - Children ages 5 to 14 by Homes with Cracks or Holes
Compare.y_axis_title: Homes with Cracks or Holes - Percent of Households 2014
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 14 Yrs Old) - Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2014

info.info_how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that reported cracks or holes in the home, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
info.info_source: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood Asthma Hospitalizations - Children ages 5 to 14 by Homes with Cockroaches
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 14 Yrs Old) - Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2014

info.info_how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that reported seeing at least one cockroach daily over the last month, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
info.info_source: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Compare.y_axis_title: Homes with 3 or More Maintenance Deficiencies - Percent 2014
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 14 Yrs Old) - Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2014

info.y_axis_title_reg: Homes with 3 or More Maintenance Deficiencies
info.info_name: Homes with 3 or More Maintenance Deficiencies
info.info_how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area reporting three or more maintenance deficiencies (heating equipment breakdown, additional heating required, rodent infestation, cracks/holes in the walls, ceilings or floors, broken plaster/peeling paint larger than 8 x 11 inches, toilet breakdowns, or water leaks from outside the unit), divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
info.info_source: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

info.y_axis_title_reg: Homes with 3 or More Maintenance Deficiencies
info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood Asthma Hospitalizations - Children ages 5 to 14 by Homes Using Supplemental Heat
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 14 Yrs Old) - Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2014

info.info_how_calculated: Estimated number of households in an area that needed to use a secondary source of heat in addition to their primary source, divided by the number of households in the area; expressed as percent.
info.info_source: New York City Housing and Vacancy Survey (HVS)

info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Compare.compare_type: Adults without a Smoke-Free Home Policy (Percent)
Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood Asthma Hospitalizations - Children ages 5 to 14 by Adults without a Smoke-Free Home Policy
Compare.y_axis_title: Adults without a Smoke-Free Home Policy - Percent 2013
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 14 Yrs Old) - Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2013

info.y_axis_title_reg: Adults without a Smoke-Free Home Policy
info.info_name: Adults without a Smoke-Free Home Policy
info.info_how_calculated: Estimated number of adults in an area without a policy that prohibits smoking anywhere in the home, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.
info.info_source: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

info.y_axis_title_reg: Adults without a Smoke-Free Home Policy
info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Compare.compare_type: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home (Percent)
Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood Asthma Hospitalizations - Children ages 5 to 14 by Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home
Compare.y_axis_title: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home - Percent 2012
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 14 Yrs Old) - Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2012

info.y_axis_title_reg: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home
info.info_name: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home
info.info_how_calculated:
Estimated number of adults in an area exposed to second-hand smoke at home, divided by all adults in the area; expressed as percent.

 

Adults who are exposed to second-hand smoke all or most of the time in their homes are considered to be exposed to second-hand smoke at home.
info.info_source: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

info.y_axis_title_reg: Adults Reporting Secondhand Smoke at Home
info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

Compare.compare_type: Adults Reporting Cockroaches in the Home (Percent)
Compare.graph_title: Neighborhood Asthma Hospitalizations - Children ages 5 to 14 by Adults Reporting Cockroaches in the Home
Compare.y_axis_title: Adults Reporting Cockroaches in the Home - Percent 2012
Compare.x_axis_title: Asthma Hospitalizations (Children 5 to 14 Yrs Old) - Rate (per 10,000 residents) 2012

info.y_axis_title_reg: Adults Reporting Cockroaches in the Home
info.info_name: Adults Reporting Cockroaches in the Home
info.info_how_calculated: Estimated number of respondents in an area that reported cockroaches in the past 30 days, divided by the number of respondents in the area; expressed as percent.
info.info_source: New York City Community Health Survey (CHS)

info.y_axis_title_reg: Adults Reporting Cockroaches in the Home
info.info_how_calculated:
Number of asthma-related hospitalizations among NYC resident children aged 5 to 14 years, divided by the population of children 5 to 14 years old, using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates; expressed as cases per 10,000 residents.

 

A hospitalization is included if it has an ICD-9 principal diagnosis code of 493 or an ICD-10 principal diagnosis code of J45. New York hospitals began using the ICD-10 system on October 1, 2015. Because the ICD systems are similar in how they classify childhood asthma, data can be compared across years.
info.info_source: New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

unreliable_text: * Estimate is based on small numbers so should be interpreted with caution.
